title: Trick-or-Treating With Food Allergies

content: I am one of those people who likes to start celebrating all things fall as early as right after the Fourth of July, hardly giving summer a chance to complete its season. Halloween is admittedly one of my favorite holidays, second only to Christmas. I love the fun, the décor, the excitement, the playfulness, and the innocence of it all. Trick-or-treating, trunk-or-treating, costumes, candy, bobbing for apples, caramel apples, you name it! I love it. It is natural for parents to want to share things that they love with their children. So naturally, when my son was diagnosed with anaphylactic peanut allergy, it felt like a punch in the gut to us both. I felt as though the innocence of this fun holiday would be swept away before he ever got the chance to enjoy it with carefree abandon.
Can My Child Enjoy Halloween with Food Allergies? Yes!

Just as I never allowed food allergies to stop us when it came to dining out, cooking, or doing arts and crafts, I knew we would find a way to overcome this obstacle as well. Having food allergies doesn’t mean that people cannot still live a whole, full life. They just need to be creative in doing it differently. Halloween remains a fan favorite in our home because we made an intentional effort to find innovative ways to create that same magic despite a food allergy.

sections.heading: Tips for an Allergy-Friendly Halloween
content: Continuing to enjoy Halloween with food allergies first meant looking at everything – gatherings, Halloween night activities, even what costume would be chosen – with a new eye. That is, an eye to all things food allergy, so that we could alter them to be food allergy-friendly. Some of the tips that remain on our list year after year include:

Consider food allergies when choosing a costume. For us, this meant no mask. We didn’t want an allergen from candy or elsewhere to get on the mask and then run down our child’s face. All it takes to cause an anaphylactic allergic reaction is for the allergen to enter the eyes, nose, or mouth. Additionally, if our child was having an allergic reaction, a mask would make it hard for us to recognize signs and symptoms.

sections.heading: Plan by bringing a Halloween food allergy pack of helpful items.
content: Items can be packed in a small backpack, fanny pack, or purse. Some of the things  we regularly have on hand when out and about for Halloween parties or trick-or-treating include hand sanitizing wipes, epinephrine, antihistamine, allergy-friendly snacks, and a bottle of water. These are the basics that we have come to need most of the time in food allergy-related situations.

sections.heading: Educate your child prior to any Halloween events.
content: This includes when shopping at the grocery store. It means showing them what different candies look like by pointing out packaging for non-allergy-friendly treats, as well as pointing out the allergy-friendly treats. This helps give your child a visual to be prepared for when the time comes to enjoy the event.

Come up with your own twist on the traditional “trick-or-treat.” As a child, I remember saying, “trick-or-treat” at each door we knocked on. When my son was younger and only allergic to peanuts, we came up with, “trick-or-treat, no nuts please.” He still got some items that had nuts, but we were pleasantly surprised by how often people picked up on what he was communicating and helped him to get something in his bag that didn’t have peanuts.

Teach your child to minimize exposure to allergens. This includes touching the candy minimally. When adults passing out candy want to drop it into the child’s bucket, we let them. It’s one less opportunity for exposure. I know of some who have their child wear gloves that appear to match the costume, but mainly serve as an extra barrier to touching allergens. Remind your child that if they do accidentally touch an allergen-containing candy to let you know, so you can help them clean their hands. One way allergens can enter the body is by touching the face, and then entering the eyes, nose, or mouth. We remind our child with food allergies frequently to avoid touching his face until he can get home to wash his hands well.

sections.heading: Teach your child to say, “no, thank you.”
content: My son has successfully been able to navigate trick-or-treating, but there have been a few households that primarily handed out candies that were laden with his allergen. In those situations, he happily said, “No, thank you. I have a peanut allergy, but Happy Halloween!” We discussed not being disappointed but choosing to be happy, and wishing others a happy evening as well. This proves to be helpful in other food allergy situations in life.

Upon arriving home, clean out your child’s candy immediately. We do not wait minutes, hours, or until the next day. Kids get excited and want to dive into that bag of candy. We sit down right away and clean out their candy, removing any that has or may contain the allergens we avoid. We then have a second person go through the candy for a “second eye” to catch any mistakes. A common phrase we use when we clean out candy is, “When in doubt, throw it out.” Any candy that is not allergen-friendly is either donated somewhere or given to the Switch Witch.

sections.heading: Create your own family tradition.
content: We take any candy that is not allergy-friendly, put it in a plastic grocery bag, and tie it shut. We have a little stuffed witch doll we call the Switch Witch. (There are several you can purchase online.) In the night, she takes the candy, the way the Tooth Fairy takes teeth that children put under pillows. In return, she leaves allergy-friendly treats or money behind. All my children have embraced The Switch Witch, even the ones with no food allergies.

Decide what to do with candy that is not allergy-friendly. Whether you decide to incorporate The Switch Witch into your family tradition, or simply clean out the candy at the end of the night with no fanfare, you will need to decide what to do with all that unwanted candy. We have done one of three things, depending on the year and what happens to be most convenient for us at the time:
bullets: Throw the candy in the garbage.
Have my husband take the candy to work to share with co-workers.

Go online to see if there is a local dentist or orthodontist in your area accepting candy donations. Sometimes, these offices will give the children something in return or take the candy and donate it to the military overseas.

sections.heading: Halloween May Look Different, But Different Isn’t Bad
content: One thing to keep in mind is that there is no one way to enjoy Halloween. There are many more ideas and traditions that you could come up with that will be unique to your family. Maybe instead of the Switch Witch, your family creates their own version with a stuffed ghost doll and comes up with their own unique name for it! Perhaps that means hosting your own Halloween party or trunk-or-treating event. Whatever it is, remember to take precautions ahead of time, educate your child on measures to avoid a reaction, and know what to do in the event of a reaction.
